Palate has a medium to slightly thin mouthfeel with average carbonation and a rather dry finish. Flavor isn’t quite as outstanding as the aroma and a little more common with some bread and biscuit. Very solid despite the ugly can.

Thanks billy from hell and wife. This brewer scores way too high on this stuff. Good for them but I think it’s unwarranted. This one pours almost chestnut with a tall lingering head that leaves snail tracks down my glass. Aromas are hopped up with a touch of malty sweetness. This beer shows only a glimpse of the style they portray to include a rather taste defying hop component that ruins the whole thing. I appreciate the difference of conquest  but I don’t drink Marzen for this.  The body is full and very malty with some goodness going on but this hopped up creep comes in a spoils the fun. As a beer by itself, it’s decent.
Very similar to the oktoberfest homebrew I brewed this fall. Lots of hops-grassy and raw. Decently nutty. Rye.

Caramel colored beer with a white head.  Aroma is grassy hops.  Flavor is certainly different for an Oktoberfest.  It’s fairly hoppy with a raw dough taste.  Palate thin, but typical for the Oktoberfest.Finishes dry.  Definitely all right.

Copper pour with a white head. Aroma of herbs, grassy/spicy hops, bread. Very interesting flavor - kind of like hopped rye bread. Mmmmm. Very long, tasty finish too. Palate is pretty standard for the style. Good beer.

The rye and extra hops make this one of the most unique oktoberfest beers I have ever tried. That being said it is particularly hoppier than a normal beer of this style. No less it is very easy to drink and is just chock full of flavor.
Can courtesy of tytoanderso.  Pours copper with a thin white head.  Smells of sage, hops, caramel.  Tastes bitter and peppery with some spice and spruce on the finish.

pours a nice copper colour with a thin head.
floral citrus hop aroma, light tea tones. 
Toasty caramel malt hiding behind a spicy citrus hop flavour.
Not anything like a marzen other than the colour, but a very enjoyable brew none the less.

How this is considered a Oktoberfest/Marzen is hard to understand.  Much closer to an dry IPA than a Marzen.  The color is pretty close to what it is supposed to be.  The head is much larger than any other Oktoberfest to date.  The head even has some lasting lacing not present in any other Marzen.  A Marzen with a floral soapy flavor, who knew?

Aroma is dense and dry with strong notes of rye, citrus, and even a hint of cabbage (not in the bad way). The pour is amber with an off-white, frothy head.
Its flavor is nothing short of remarkable - a complex blend of cinnamon, hops, nutmeg, and even a hint of smoke predominate finishing into a long, slightly bitter end.
An absolute must for smoked cheeses and bratwursts.

16oz can. Pours a clear coppery amber with a firm off-white head.  Aroma is light and sweet, with hints of citrusy hops, grain, tea, and a faint bit of spice.  Taste is medium-bodied, with a taste of malt, caramel, and grain giving way to a slightly astringent finish of floral and syrupy hops, spices, and tea.  A perfectly good Oktoberfest beer, though I can’t help but think Surly could have done a bit better.

Canned. Medium copper colored body with a very light khaki head. The aroma was cereal grains with some sweet mango. There was also some nice dusty caramel and hints of black tea. The taste was rich toffee and iced tea. There was also some burnt toast in the finish. I enjoyed this other than the burning tasted finish.

Draught at Kuma’s Corner, Chicago, IL.   Light copper golden with a thin off-white head.  Soapy citrus hops aroma and flavor with a thin body.  Does not really have the malt body you expect in a marzen and comes across a bit as a week pale ale to me.  Not bad.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2010 [Can] Pours a beautiful amber color with a soapy beige head. Aroma is floral, fresh hops, a bit of bready and caramel malt, and light lager yeast. The flavor is crisp but a touch on the sweeter side. The lager yeast is evident, light hop bitterness, some fruit snack and caramel sweetness, and lightly toasted malts. Fantastic beer and I think it takes the place of bitter brewer as my favorite Surly seasonal.

Pours a hazy golden honey yellow with thick cream colored head. Aroma is citrus hops, dried pineapple, tropical fruits. Flavor is dried fruit and hops. The dried fruit comes through in this burst of condensed sugars that come through... reminiscent to the intense flavor of dried fruit. A very floral beer/citrus beer all around. But I do love this version of Oktoberfest. I really enjoy this beer. Body is a bit creamier with definite carbonation to counter it.

Draft @ The Happy Gnome.  Pours a bright, clear orange color; off-white head with good retention and fine-bubbled lacing; bright, nice pour.  Juicy oranges, resiny dripping tree fruit and tropical notes in the aroma; papaya and lime; very soft.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: resiny oranges, dry citrus, and light chewy maltiness; dry, solidly hopped Oktoberfest, very drinkable.  Excellent, unique rendition.  Medium finish: dry toasty malts, orange and lasting mineral bitterness; nicely dry.
Pours a hazy amber. The nose is very floral. Comes across the palate very smooth; not too hoppy. Has a funominal finish that lingers.

Tap at Mad Capper in Stillwater.  Pint appears copper amber with a nice white head and lace.  The aroma is a solid malt foundation with some hops to show through.  The flavor was much the same as the aroma, with a decent body for it being a lager.  Overall, not my favorite Surly by any means, but not bad and a nice change of pace.

16 oz can.  Pours a nice orange/ light copper color with an off white head that laces very nicely.  Aroma is very strong on the citrus hops initially and then the caramel maltiness moves in to somewhat balance out the aroma...still a little heavy on the hops.  Flavor is a nice sweet maltiness with a bit of citrus hops to back.  Kinda weird because the aroma is the exact opposite.  Very smooth and rather balanced.  The mouthfeel it a bit thin for how bold the flavor is but..it is a lager, no worries.  I love that they call this their "interpretation of a German Oktoberfest" because that is what it tastes like:  Surly does Oktoberfest.  Worthwhile.

Not being a fan of lagers, I’m impressed.  On tap at SurlyFest 2008, pours a dark copper with white head.  Aroma is pleasantly balanced of hops, yeast and malt.  Flavor is hops initially, finishing with the yeast and malt.  Palate is thin but good for a lager and has a slight bitterness.  Definitely a good lager.
Fina example of a Marzen.  Because it is a lager, it lacks the body I usually like in a beer, but this beer tasted nice and had a good hop presence.  Here’s to the can!

The beer was copper colored with a decent amount off-white head. The citrus hops are dominate in the bouquet of hops that they used. Tastes like furious with caramel malt. Which cuts the hops in a good way and makes it more drinkable.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2008 Summit hops eh? Dont believe Im too familiar with many beers that use this hop. Nice to see it showcased here, with noticable bitterness. Perfect appearance. Copper with a light beige head. Aroma is spicy hop blending with the signature breadiness of an Oktoberfest. Mine was a little too cold when I poured it so the hops were big in my face and huge on the tongue. As it warms up a bit its much more balanced right now. About 3/4 of the way through this glass and it keeps getting better....Nice bready flavor with the hops being there just to complement with spiciness and a snappy finish. Right amount of carbonation. Not sticky and heavy like some INFERIOR Oktoberfests. ;) Love the toffee, bread and spiciness of this beer. Must be the Rye...Another balanced one that I consider one of those that illustrates "what beer tastes like". Excellent stuff. Would like to have some with a little time on it just to see if the hops mellow a tad.
Comes in a Can. Loved the checks on the can as well.  Pours an amber orange with a big white head.  Aroma and flavor is german malts, crisp sweet malt, some hops and pine.  Another solid surly!
Can at DLD:  Copper in color.  There was a nice balance of hops and malt in this medium-bodied beer.  It was a bit hard to taste this will all of the other heavy beers on the table.

Clear copper in colour, thin off-white coloured head, light lacing.  The aroma is quite hoppy, cereal and grains, lightly sweet, floral hops.  The flavour has some earthy malts, lots of cereal, lightly toasty, moderate floral hop bite.  Mildly bitter mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes bready, floral, lightly with some light alcohol.
A very weird and crazy Oktoberfest beer, very hoppy.  A German IPA?  Its not to bad but the hops where an unnecessary distraction.
473ml can obtained in a trade with Beerlando, thanks Bryan.
Opened on December 16, 2007.
No date.

Bottle courtesy of Oakbluff: Poured a deep slightly hazy amber color ale with a thick foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma consists of big semi-sweet malt rye with some dry hops. Taste is also dominated by big rich malt with the typical rye taste and some light dry hops at the end. Full body with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Very refreshing beer but also very filling which mean I wouldnt have that much in a session. Also, I was expecting a hop bomb as this brewery is quite good at those but this is somewhat close to the original style.

A- Pours a deep orange hue with a small but sustainable eggshell head.

S- Smells of fragrant hops, malty sweetness.

T- Taste is incredible. Spicy, malty, nutty, typical oktoberfest beer on steroids.

M- Medium viscosity, light on the carbonation.

D- This is extremely drinkable. I could easily drink these until I passed out from the alcohol and deliciousness.

Pours a dark hazy yellow/gold.  Aroma of honeydew and melons.  The hops are immediately noticeable which is crazy in a Marzen.  Sweet malty, piney and honey in the flavor.  Crisp soda like body with a bit of stickiness.  Bring on Oktober!

16oz can-pours an off white head and hazy amber color.  Aroma is medium malt, then lots of sweet lemon/pine hops.  Great out of the standard style (continental hops out, northwest in!) American interpretation.  Taste is medium malt-caramel, then lots of sweet lemon/pine hops-slightly bitter, more aromatic. OK effervescence/soft carbonation.  Nice.  Thanks to Wasatch(BA).

16 oz. can courtesy of Secret Santa.  Pours a hazy golden orange with a moderate off-white head that lasted through the first one-third of the glass and left partial lacing.  Pleasant aroma of malt and floral hops.  The flavor is more dominated by hops than malt, which is atypical of the style.  Hoppy, somewhat bitter finish.  Very drinkable, but not what I think of when I think Oktoberfest.
Can. Cloudy golden colour with a white head. Aroma of german hops, notes of pines, rye and maltness. Flavour of hops, malt very dry and very untraditionel oktoberfest bier.

Can from a trade with TyAnderso One of the better Marzens Ive had. Hoppier than most but thats probably why I like it more. Pours a nice deep orange color. Sweet sticky hop & malt character. Slightly doughy. Nice creamy mouthfeel. Real nice

Can from trade with akevitt. Thanks Jason. It poured an almost clear orange golden body and a white head. Thats quite normal for an oktoberfest. What surprised me was the lovely hop profile in this beer. It was packed full of apricot, flowers and pine, as well as some resin and a maltyness trying to balance it. The flavor isnt on the same level, but sure something for a hophead. Theres still the lovely apricot, flower and pine, but its too high on bitterness. Full body and a long, long hoppy finish. Lager, who should have thought that. (080216)

Tasted 2/25/08.  1PT Can.  Slightly hazy with an amber golden hue.  Clinging off-white head.  Herbal hoppy nose.  Big sweet sticky crisp body.  Good candy floral rose petal yeast character.  Bitter rye.  Sticky yet crisp.  Citrus malts and a touch in the yeast palate.  Good finish.  Fun drinking!

Can shared by yngwie, thanks!
This is no Octoberfest beer!
Lovely aroma of apricot and flowers. Trainloads of hoppiness, grass, flowers, dust. Great stuff!

Can courtesy of Secret Santa.  Pours a dark golden color with a good sized fluffy white head.  The aroma has floral and citrus hops with lighter moderate sweet malt in the background.  Really reminds me more of an IPA.  The flavor opens with the same hoppiness as the nose.  More malt presence appears in the middle.  Finish is back to hops. Enjoyable, but Im not sure if it fits the style.

Can provided and shared by Yngwie, thanks. Stable white head. Golden/copper colored body.  Beautiful smell of summerflowers up front. Spice and citrus to come. Whiffs of toasted malts. Citrussy and malty taste with some prominent bittering hops taking the lead all the way towards finish. Well-bodied. Lingering bitterness in the finish. Festbier plus!, very nice.

your perty red/gold with a head that sticks around... when cold not malty enough for me and very much like the furious which isnt bad, but not too exciting either. Im not all about rating to style... but ot quite what I expected... still, not bad. much better, more marzen-ny upon warming.. bumping the score up a bit

GABF 2007. Beer is light, clear, oxidized-looking gold with a small, white, frothy, mostly and quickly diminishing head.

The aroma is neat-o;redolent of autumnal vegetation. Its malty with light notes of toasted grain, biscuit, trace of caramel; Hoppy with moderate/heavy notes of resin/pine, light/moderate notes of fall leaves and sap, lemon zest, trace of tea; Yeasty with a trace of dough.

The flavor is moderately/heavily sweet, moderately acidic,lightly bitter with a long, moderately bitter, light/moderately acidic and sweet finish. Light/moderate alcohol warmth in the aftertaste.

The body is medium, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

Pretty swell.

Courtesy SoLan.  Slightly cloudy rich orange copper color with a thin white layer of head.  Sweet grainy nose, apricots, light hops.  Slightly astringent start, carbonation a bit low.  Grainy throughout, sweetness stays in check.  Smells better than it iasted.

16 oz can, via tytoanderso.  Pours a clear deep orange to copper body under a one finger fizzy off-white head.  Some very fine lacing remained.  Whoa!  The nose is big green leafy hops over a toasted malt base.  The rye is more of an accent, but clearly noticable.  Not the aroma one expects for an O-fest.  Weird.  Thats the first word that came to mind with the first sip.  Its like a bite of a leafy herbal hop cone sandwich on rye bread with a touch of honey.  What a crazy beer.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with nice soft fizzy carbonation and a lingering bitterness.  Overall, this was pretty awesome.  An unusual hybrid for sure.  I think I want more of this.

Can. An orange beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with primary notes of grapefruit, while the flavor is sweet with strongest notes of grapefruit, but also notes of malt and caramel. Much more like an IPA, than an Oktoberfest - maybe a Minnesota Oktoberfest ;-) Thanks Papsoe for sharing.

Exotic cinnamon and citrus hops with a noble core.  American nobles?  Attractive voluminous head atop a deep amber body.  Nice, long maltiness, with an underlying bitterness, that supports rather than detracts.  Actually the maltiness is really fantastic.  Long and rich without being boozy as some festbiers can be.  This is really exceptional.  Thanks a ton Joey!

Pours a chestnut brownm redolent of Fall in Vermont.   Aroma is surprisingly hoppy, though the malts do come shining through.   The flavor is more of the same, with the hops coming through.  Nice brew.
2007. Amber. Small, off white head. Flavor and aroma of toasty, biscuity malt, light dose spicy rye, and some earth, bitter hops. Medium body, balanced carbonation. Solid.

2007 version courtesy of beerlando, thanks Bryan! This one poured a coppery ambery color with a medium foamy white head that left some nice lacing. The aroma was of sweet malts, caramel, toasted malts, and a good amount of hops. The flavor follwed suit with the caramel and toasted malts up front, but with a good amount of hop bitterness on the back end. Quite different for an Octoberfest beer to have this much hops. Medium bodied with a smooth and sticky mouthfeel that had a nice hop bitterness finish to it. Pretty well done for this style, and interesting take especially coming out of a can.

(Can 47,5 cl) Courtesy of Skyview. Slightly hazy, amber golden with a creamy, off-white head. Very fresh and piney aroma. Medium body with light caramel accents and otherwise completely dominated by the very dry, piney aroma hoppiness. Distinctly bitter finish. Excellent, but in style very far from an Oktoberfest! If this was served in the beer halls of Munich, the poor local beerdrinkers would never what hit them... 110108

Can.
Cloudy orange coloured with an off white head.
Fruity aroma of hops, grape fruits, pine apples and apricots.
Hoppy flavour of pine needles, grape fruits, fruits and grass.
Dry hoppy finish.

Bottle. [Great two day tasting session @ Papsoe] Average fizzy white head that mostly diminished. Fair display of lacework. Light cloudy amber color. Aroma of pine, grapefruit, citrus, fruit, caramel. Over the palate moderated floral and grapefruit notes. Moderated bitter flavor with counter sweetness. Dry and bitter floral finish.

47.5 cL can. Pours hazy orange with a diminished white head. Aroma is slight spiced, solid floral hoppy aroma. Flavour is medium sweet and solid fruity towards fresh fruity hoppy. Ends very fresh fruity. Nice ipa by all means, but this ha very little to do with a classic Octoberfestbier.

Thanks skyview.  The aroma is very nice.  Hoppy fest smells.  Grains, bready caramel, and tons of hops.  The beer pours to a pale amber body.  The flavor is grains, breads, o-fest flavors.  Very nice and quite hoppy.  I thought this was a great beer.

Semi hazed and amber orange in color with grey webs spanning the top. Aroma is indeed hoppy, with grapefruit and starfruit aiding the citric shine, then reveling in toasted Munich malt, wheat bran, tangerines and livid caramelized dates. Flavor confirms the c-hop presence. A touch of oxidized caramel dates, candied apples and balancing Munich complexity aid the show. Rustic cotton steel meets citrus hop shines. Tangerines get heeled and spread on mandarin buttered baguettes. Orange candy crusted wheat flakes support the ample carbonation throughout. Bitter sweet orange toffee wraps everything up in a bow. Thanks, Bob!

can...thanks to incutrav for this one...poured a murky caramel brown with a decent sized off-white head....the nose of this reminded me of a ipa actually which was surprising and well welcomed.  very big flowery hop aroma that jumps out of the glass....flavors of hops, malt, and also some soft peppery spice notes.  it finishes off with some grapefruit bitterness......an admirable oktoberfest beer that i woud gladly have again.

16oz can. thanks pantanap for sharing. pours red with white head. nose is fresh, bready and hoppy. flavor is bready, hoppy, and piney. good body and carbonation. a solid oktoberfest brew that i look forward to trying a bit fresher next year.

Despite being around for a couple years, I still cant quite help getting a kick out of it every time I pop the tab of a canned craft-brew.  The beer pours with a lightly hazy, reddish amber color and is topped by a frothy, initially two-finger thick, light tan colored, textured head that is creamy enough to leave a layered lacing pattern on the sides of my glass as I slowly consume the beer.  Spicy notes of grain and hop mix wonderfully in the aroma; slightly grassy, definite earthy rye spice aromatics as well as an herbal, candied lemon zest & currant hop character.  Toasty malt notes and a touch of caramelized grain sugars enter in towards the finished spurring the imagination towards thoughts of brown sugar crusted, marmalade coated, toasted, organic, artisinal bread that has been crushed into an aromatic powder.  Quite an interesting aroma; very enticing, entirely engaging and hearty enough to be a harvest time tipple.

Well carbonated, which combines with a sharp hop character that is both herb focused and lemon zest like.  Grassy hop notes combine with a soft, yet gripping, bitterness in the finish.  The rye does not add a whole lot to the flavor, but does seem to contribute a grassy slightly spicy note that lingers long after a sip has past down my throat.  The rye does seem to contribute to the body of the brew as this has a definite viscous heft to it without being cloying.  Grassy flavors, touches of currants and a certain menthol like note all seem to be part of the hop profile.

The grassy hop character seems to grow a bit as the beer warms up a bit, coupled with a sort of pine / menthol note (but not in the typical American hop way), this becomes the dominant, though not quite defining, characteristic of this brew.  If you hadnt guessed this really is quite hoppy, definitely a hop dominated brew; sort of like a cross between an IPA and a malty Oktoberfest.  Quite tasty, a really enjoyable brew and I am glad they did not brew another typical Oktoberfest (while I do enjoy a well crafted traditional one, truly great ones are few and far between).  Perhaps my only complaint is that the hops get in the way of really noticing the rye character.
Pours an amber color, with a big off white head that disappears quickly. Lots of spotty lacing. Not my style of beer, a litte too hopy for an Octoberfest. A litte dry and bitter for my taste.
user_location: Mescal Lakes (wherever that is), Arizona, USA

text: 16 oz. can via trade with tytoanderso - Pours a slightly hazy deep amber color with a one and a half finger thick off white head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is light hops and toasted malt.   Flavor is hops and esters.  Medium body.  A good, hop forward Maren.  Thanks Tyler.

Pours a deep burned orange with 2 fingers of soapy white head that dies slowly. I know this is a marzen but I know its a Surly marzen which makes alll the difference. Smells of piney hops, citrus, rye and malty. Ooooh yeah. Tastes of juicy, piney hops, malty balance and delicious rye. This is the brilliant nectar named Furious but tamed down with more flavors. If I could make a perfect octoberfest beer to suit my hophead tastes, it would be almost as good as this. Medium in the mouth with the perfect tickle of carbonation. Drinkability? If I had a case of this I would drink non stop and end up in a hospital and it would be so worth it.

Can coutesy of skyview. Sweet malt and some citrus hop aroma. Orange body with good head. Flavor had enough sweet citrus tomellow out the spicey bitterness. Dry bittering finish but good beer. Thanks Bob.

Cheesehead YeAH 2007, thanks Bob for the can: Amber hue with a frothy head and spotty lace. The aroma has notes of caramel, herbal and grassy hops, pepper and pear esters. The taste is malty sweet with a herbal hop bitterness. A spicy and woody finish. The mouth feel is lively and sprite, clean finish. A nice brew for a can but has the trappings of the style.

Thanks again to Bob!  Poured clear medium caramel with a short cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up super grapefruit and piney hoppage all over.. medium-skinned fruit and caramel sweetness below, which was enough to support the hops.. this was cool twist on the style, as I enjoyed the hop assault.  The flavor had primarily fruity sweetness along with some caramel supporting huge doses of pine and grapefruit bitterness.. long, bitter finish to it.. tasty!  Almost too bitter on the palate, and it couldve used more toasty malts.  Good stuff!

12-14-07 can shared with lb4lb courtesy of tytoanderso. 

Thick orange amber with the best head ever - thick, fluffy, long-lasting and so pretty.  Aroma is a hoppy sweet blend that depicts the Oktoberfest ideally. Great texture - not thin or watery.  Hops flavor is present, especially in the finish.  I would like a bit more hops in the flavor overall though - but this is highly drinkable and enjoyable.

Bottle courtesy of trade with tytoanderso
Pours a gorgeous autumnal amber color with a big sudsy lace inducing head.  Smell is fresh and vibrant and wow, there are actually big fresh hops in this oktoberfest!  Smell is hoppy, yet apples and sweet malt as well.  Amazing for a style I usually find pretty average.  Taste is nice, and mildish aside from a decent dose of grassy hopping and a nice bitterness level.  Easy on the malt, and not a sweet or tart oktoberfest like Im used to but more mildly sharp and zesty, perhaps from the Crystal Rye.  A touch on the thin side palatewise, although the carbonation is spot on.  A great, unique oktoberfest although I would actually like a hint more sweetness here.  Big thanks for the can, Tyler!
Can thanks to Jeppe (Ølbutikken). A amber beer with a big off-white head. Malty, bready, floral hop aroma and taste, fresh. Medium body with a dry finish.

16 oz. can. Strong, clean, yeasty smell. Herbs and spices (oregano, tyme, chives, cilantro) dominate the unique aroma. Smells like a lager version of a Christmas ale. Pours a mostly clear copper color with just a touch of haze. Large amount of fluffy, uneven, yellow-tinted, cream/light tan head. Produces thick lacing. Very nice, clean appearance. Hops dominate the flavor to a remarkably high degree. All of the spices present in the aroma also appear in the flavor. Bitter. A touch of citrus, especially grapefruit. A bit of underlying floral sweetness, but, for the most part, the malts are subdued. Dried leaf flavor that makes the beer taste like autumn. That presumably derives from the dry-hopping process. Dry finish. Long, herbal, bitter aftertaste. Light body. Oaty softness in the palate, but that probably results from the water used rather than actual oats. Interesting palate effects, but it is so soft and light that it feels insubstantial in the mouth. SurlyFest is not as malt-forward and far hoppier than a traditional Oktoberfestbier. Thats okay with me, as Im not a big marzen fan. This is probably my least favorite Surly product, but it fits well within their modus operandi of brewing unique, style-bending beers. I am rating from the sixth can of this beer that Ive tried, and Ive felt basically the same way about this beer each time.

Canned sample via oakbluff. Vibrant orange in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas of bready malts and grassy and vaguely citrusy hops (although definitely not C-hops). More bread-biscuit notes in the mouth, and a whole lotta hop flavor for an "oktoberfest". Medium bodied, refreshing, and slightly bitter. Very solid stuff.

2007 batch.  Pours a clear copper-amber body with a medium, foamy, off-white head.  A good amount or ribbony lacing decorated the glass well.  The aroma showed sweet caramel, sugar glazed biscuit, toast, and a surprisingly ample grassy hoppiness.  The flavor was again based on sweet caramel malts, with toasty cookie dough and strong grassy and resinous hops.  Finishes grassy and fresh.  Smooth, medium body that is just a bit to sticky for me, but not annoyingly so.  Very drinkable.  This is a pretty big beer, probably the biggest Oktoberfest Ive had.  Id classify it as an Imperial Oktoberfest if such a thing exists.

Can from theisti.  Thanks!Pours a nice cheddar orange with an aroma of tangy candied hops with pine raisin.  Matly underbelly in the nose as well. Flavor is thin daggers of grassy hops and grapefruit.  Average mouthfeel.  Another quality brew from Surly.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Can: Pours a copper with a slight haze to it, with an off white head. Aroma, spices, yeasty, with some pine and earthy notes, pale malts. Flavor, caramel and an herbal floral quality to it, some yeast, there are some really bright hops to this one, with a good bit of bitterness on the finish. Quite enjoyable.

Poured from a 16oz can and served in a Bells dimpled mug.  This beer poured a slightly hazy, glowing amber/orange with visible carbonation running up the glass, topped by a fomy, beige head that lasted throughout.  Some chunky lacing was left around the glass.  The aroma of the beer included an abundance of fragrent floral hops, caramel, and toasted malt.  Great aroma with a nice, unexpected hop presence.  The flavor was very malty with toasted grains, caramel, light toffee, and a spicy hop finish.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with soft carbonation that provided a creamy palate.  This was just a kick ass Oktoberfest!  Maybe a bit overhopped for the purist, but I thank Surly for pushing the envelope a little bit.  Great job!!!

Shared by Sliffy.  Wonderful aroma--nice hop scent with a good "harvest ale" type of of aroma.  Body is orange-brown with a decent head.  The taste is great for the style--nice rye flavor for sure with a healthy dose of hops on top.  The hops are grassy and fit well with this style.

Thanks to drmatt for sharing this nice marzen.  This is one of the fest o-fest beers I think I could care about.  Pours orange / copper with a light white head.  The aroma has floral / flowery hops with some dank green onions and light citrus.  Medium / light body with a crisp and lightly brash carbonation.  The flavor starts with some caramel malt first then quickly the hops from the aroma take over.  The finish focuses mainly on the dank and citrus aspects.  Very well done non-typical version of the style.

GABF 2007.  Mostly transparent, copper brown color with a creamy beige head.  Grassy, herbal hop aromas with a touch of caramel sweetness and nutty notes.  Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel.  Lots of caramel flavor and loads of herbal hop bitterness.  Obviously not to style, but I desperately wish it was, as this is not at all in my lines of flavor preference.  Im completely missing the point, as I dont like my IPAs to be malty, nor do I like my octoberfests to be laden with caramel.

This was like no other Marzen Ive ever had. Extremely crisp and clean, with a lot of hop character. Some notes of rye, maybe? Flavorful, herbal hoppy to the finish. Real style buster, but very good. Thanks to theisti for the trade!

Can, with thanks to both theisti and tytoanderso, appreciate it guys!  Pours a slightly cloudy orange amber with a towering pillowy tan head, great lacing.  Aroma is fruits and light spice, with some apple peel, peach and caramel.  Flavor is malty, with touches of apple peel, caramel and toffee; only the slightest of hoppiness detected.  A nice interpretation of the style and highly quaffable!

From a Big Boy Can. O ya. Pours out a nice hazy copper topped with a off white head. Aroma of malt and some hops. Tast of sweet fruit and a little hops. I also picked up a touch of spice. thanks Jake.

Can from Tytoanderso - Thanks!  Pours a mildly hazy orange with a smaller beige head.  Aroma of fruits, mainly citrus, and hints of maltiness,  Flavor is fruity and crisp, citrus, apple, apricot blend before the hops meet in the tail.  Interesting take on the style.
Orange amber with a small off white head.  Light malty aroma.  Apples and other mild fruit.  Malty flavor with a bit of citrusy hops.

Can: Pale gold color, light head. nose of bright fruit, some apple and vanilla, odd urinal cake notes. The flavor is weird and medicinal, lots of herbal notes, odd urinal cake notes continue. Very herby. Ehh.

Can.  Poured a clear copper color with a medium white head. Good lacing. Aroma is excellent, as it is hoppier than youd imagine for an Oktoberfest (although for Surly, I guess it should be expected). As for that flavor, wow! Im impressed. As a fan of the style, this is a much bolder flavor. It has the caramel and maltiness to it that I like, but it has a super hoppy finish to it. 

I had my doubts from reading other reviews, but this is very nice. Thanks theisti!!!

This shit is good.  Aroma is slightly dank onion and lagery.  I cant explain it, but its appealing.
Taste is slightly salty, oniony, just yummy.  
Finishes clean and crisp, but nice and malty too.  Jesus, I cant write tonight.  
This shit is good.  Enough said.
GABF 2007:  Poured a golden color with an off-white head.  Caramel and toasty aroma.  Some earthy and piney hops.  Malty caramel flavor.  Decent beer.

Thanks to theisti for this Surly...love those guys. Golden pour with nice big white head. Hoppy nose with nice pine aromas. Taste is doughy malt with rye, grass, melon, citrus....lots going on really. Good carbonation that leaves a great finish. Not really sure what style this is, but I really love it. Thanks T.

Can. Malty. Smells like Furious. Clear, dark amber with very little visible carbonation. Good hop profile for the style. Good brew. Thanks Vikingbeau for bringing this down for me from the Twin Cities.

Pint-sized can from tytoandero - thanks! What a fine improvisation on the well-worn style, and this is an auspicious introduction to the world of Surly for me. Lovely and dry, but not at the expense of malts; rather, theres a kind of combo fullness, both rich and notably rooted in the rye. Quite satisfying.

Thanks to tytoanderso for the can. Aroma of sweet grains and caramel with the addition of big pine and citrus hops. Fruity taste, along with the malts and hops. Whenever I drink Surly, Im amazed at how fresh the beer tastes. This is no exception.

16 oz. can from Blue Max in Burnsville, MN.  Pour is clear orange amber with lots of carbonation bubbles and a one inch slightly off white head.  Aroma of fresh pine hops, earthiness and some resin.  Taste has quite a bit of the bitter hop bite to start, malt in the middle and earthiness in there as well.  The taste also features a sweetness that I can;t quite put my finger on.  Its a bitter sweetness, but not quite citrus.  The sweetness is more in the malt than the hop.   I have had this beer a number of times, and even still have a great deal of trouble figuring it out.  Its interesting, and I can honestly not figure out whether I like it or not.

drank a ton of this stuff on tap last year and never got around to reviewing. Now that its canned, I may consume it within the comforts of home and the computer.
Brilliant orange color, very shiny with a halo of yellow nearer the bottom and edges. Firmly stacked foam of spongy looking consistancy lathers up to a decent height of nearly two inches. Dwindles down slowly to let loose a pattern of thin inky strings across the glass as its consumed.

Aroma is much like other O-fests with a nice firm realm of maltyness creating a sweet soft doughyness and a puff of dark grassyness and whole grains can be easily detected within. Very well-balanced aroma and well placed on the nose with good strength.

Taste is a broadly detailed malt brigade of heavy toasted malty sweetness, doughy, crisp with a spectacular grassy grab at the midway point which then goes all hoppy and drys off the palate with a subtle ease and tone that is incredibly delightful and inviting with grass, toast, and whole grain nuttyness. Quite complexingly subtle and straight up damn yummy.

Feel is about medium with a certain crispness to its malty body. For surely clean and easy. Has a creamy stained under carraige but stays mostly toasted and drys into the finish with a lushfully charming and soothing softness and cleanness with a willingness to venture more.

Drinkable and then some. Enough said. Damn solid O-fest by Surly! Grab your lederhosen, a big Ol mug, pour a bunch of this in, and sing yourself a song until you fall asleep and do it again.

16oz can from hellomynameis, thanks Zac!  Clear darkish orange with a one finger beige head, fading before long to a ring and thick film.  Tropical fruit and caramel malt nose.  There is also an underlying grainy character.  Flavor adds plenty of fresh herbal hops into the mix, as well as some toasty malts and spicy rye.  Bitterness peaks around a 3 or 4. Medium body with light creamy carbonation.This is a very strange beer, but as I finish the can, I realize I like this quite a bit.

text: (Draught)  Pours a clear golden body with a moderate off-white head.  Aroma of florals, melon, caramel, apple, and citrus.  Flavor of citrusy hops, herbs, and toasted malt.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2009 A can courtesy of theisti. Omar doesnt really believe in brewing beers to style and SurlyFest is no exception. Pours a clear light copper with a loose, frothy, beige head that leaves wispy lace behind. The hops definitely dominate the nose on this "Oktoberfest", with spicy/earthy hops backed by notes of bready malt, light rye, faint tobacco and candy sugar. The mouthfeel is medium-bodied and almost creamy with a tight bitter finish. The flavor follows the nose with a solid hop hit up front with notes of rye, Munich malt, cigarette tobacco (not great) and faint caramel. Overall this seems like a blend of a well-hopped APA and a rye-Oktoberfest. Definitely a unique brew and one that is worth trying if you get the chance. Thanks for sharing this one with us, Tim
finally a hopped up oktoberfest. great color and nice lacy head. fruity hints of fruis as well. honey an rye as  well just a great beer nice work again.
Honey malt aroma with spicy hops.  Pours dark blonde to amber.  Smooth and malty, honey malts, light a little different for a fest beer, but good.
Big thanks to tytoanderso for suppling! Poured amber with fluffy white head. Aroma of hops and sweet malt. Big hop flavor surprisingly with a nice sweet malt backgroung. Some fruit hints present.

16oz. can.  Nicely aromatic, full and well-hopped with notes of flowers, dried leaves, fresh wood, earth, pine, orange and candyish brown sugar, some light biscuity maltiness here as well.  Translucent light-medium orange amber color with a lasting, ivory head.  Flavor is nicely balanced between the nutty, toasty, light caramel malt sweetness and rather substantial hop bitterness, and features suggestions of citrus, pine, and a pleasant spiciness courtesy of the rye.  Finishes fairly dry and crisp, some lingering hop resins here.  Nicely active, clean mouthfeel with a light-medium body.  Certainly not what one typically sees from this style, but is nicely flavorful and pretty interesting stuff.  Cheers to theisti!
Copper color nice tan well laced head.  Very hoppy aroma, not recognized but some sweet grains.  Avg pal.  Grainy well hopped grass finish some caramel.  not like any okt Ive ever had but not bad.

16oz can from theisti. Aroma is melanoidins, caramel, and floral, mildly spicy hops. Copper colored with a two fingered head and active carbonation. Initial taste is earthy, spicy rye followed by a huge rush of bitterness, bread crust, more earthiness, and some caramel. It certainly is an interesting beer, I got two and I drank one yesterday at a football game (out of the can) and this one today the proper way. The malt bill is unique, to be sure, the rye gives it a lot of the earthiness and spiciness you might from the traditional hops used in a Märzen, but the American hops give it a distinct flavor. It is a nice drinking beer, but I would like it to be a touch maltier. All in all a tasty beer, but I hope that next years version retains the general idea (rye, american hops and lots of them) but approaches it in a general direction.   Brewers notes for the 2007 version  Brewed with Vienna,Pilsen and Rye malts.German Lager yeast.Kettle and dry hopped with Sterling.
abv 6.3%
ibu 35

16 ounce can from theisti
Pours amber/brown with a foamy dense cream colored head.  Left behind some nice lace.
Killer aroma.  Not really an oktoberfest aroma, but really interesting.  Theres the rye, that I feel is the upfront character.  Then there a pronounce grassy dry hop character.
Okay, Im on the fence with the flavor.  The rye and all the hops are confusing.  I know.  Thats the point.  Rye chracater abounds.  Sort of an aggressive noble hops flavor and brash bitterness.  Things seem to blend and present themselves better at warmer temps.
The palate is right on.  Medium body on the full side of medium.  Lively but not aggressive carbonation.  Dry finish.
The RB description states that this beer was made with Summit.  I have read in places that that wast the 06 version.  The 07 version was made with Sterling hops.  I would suspect that these hops would lend completly differenct character to the beer.  Anyway, what we have here is another original and interesting beer from our friends at Surly.

(sample from irishboy)rusty colored body with an off white head.the aroma blends earth.citrus,hops,and caramel malts.the flavor is a nice mix of the aroma.is this a hopped up Oktoberfest?if it is im liking it.
16 oz can from tytoanderso; copper with a big yellowish glass-lacing head; nose of grassy and floral hops and caramel; flavor of hop bitterness, a little rye grain, and caramel.
Its a good beer, but doesnt taste what I think of as an oktoberfest. It has a very distinct sweet flavor and is very light but refreshing.

12-oz aluminum can. Thanks, Franksnbeans! Pours coppery rubied amber with a thick sudsy off-white head. Gargantuan cannabinoid nose. Medium body, nice level sweetness, perfectly modulated accentual carb. Lovely stuff--easy-going mid-palate of caramel, nuts, toast, biscuit, and fruity hops. Lovely.

16 oz can. Damn, i really dig the cans. Pour it into a glass, no worries about skunkiness. Anyway, this beer claims to have rye in it. After a few sips this becomes noticeable, with that little bit of toasted rye going on. Otherwise smooth clean malts, with a bit of hops to back it up. Surly once again solid.

16 fl. oz. can, pours a coppery orange with bubbly yellow-white head.  Sour, citrus and hop aromas.  Mostly hoppy taste with some slight caramel/citrus flavors.  Hop flavors tend to dominate the light body and palate.  A little too sour and bitter for my tastes.  Dry finish with an aftertaste that has a medicine (aspirin/astringent) tone.

Clear medium amber-red with a medium-dense light tan head.  The aroma is somewhat off--there is some hops character there but it is surmounted by a combination of grain and lager fermentation aromas that initially form something off-putting.  Beyond that, the flavor is crisp with nice grain notes--rye--hops bitterness, a hint of fruitiness, and some lager yeast notes.  The body is light but has good presence and finishes pleasantly bitter and dry.

Very interesting rendition here.  Not unlike Surly to push the style designations, this tastes like no other Octoberfest Ive ever had.  Perfume, grass, citrus, and mango aromas.  Some grape? in the flavor.  Hoppy profile along with a tinge of rye.  Ill say it again, very interesting.

Deep, clear foxy colour, with fluffy, off-white head. Absolutely beautiful C-hops, but mildly dosed, very aromatic, dry hopbales and ending in a meaty, even fishy ester. Bitterish and none-too-sweet caramel. Rather well balanced. Nettlecheese and hops (hopscheese?). I wonder where/if the rye contributes. Slight slickness, dry finish. Wow, thanks David - this is one great, unusual lager. More of that!
odd oktoberfest style. reminds me of the surly furious. smell and taste like pine hops with a little malt flavor.

Well that was different. Not at all what I expected from an Oktoberfest style. The aroma was dominated by pine hops and so was the flavor. Maybe a bit of caramel and very bitter. This is more like an IPA. Not really to my taste.
Tastes and smells like a caramel malted furious.  Not bad, with plenty of hops and a brown color.

Picked up single 16-oz can at Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul, MN. Pours a coppery amber brew with a decent off-white head that has good retention and lacing. Aroma of piney Summit hops (almost more/like Cascade), with caramel malt, some sweet honeydew, and a touch of yeast. Taste is lightly carbonated, medium bodied, with a decent bitter caramel flavor. Finish is more bitter than the normal sweet after taste that oktoberfest brews have. But then again, this is Surly! Yah, dis goot-en hoppy!

Dark copper color with a thin head.  Powerful hop aroma that is all Noble.  Id bet on Hallertauer.  Very bitter taste with tons of same hop variety from the aroma.  Almost a Lysol effect, but in a good way.  Slight rye notes and a slightly dry/bitter malty finish.  Normal Octoberfest?  Hell no!

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2007 Pours a burnt roasty auburn/brown.  Nice citrusy nose with a hint of roasted malt and melon.  Very hoppy flavor like Furious, but there is a roasted malty character alongside an almost astringent character.  Not my favorite Surly, but nice nonetheless.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Can. Quite hoppy on the nose with a hint of rich and spicy rye malt to balance. Theres also an interesting dry, leafyness to it. Almost smells like a crisp, October afternoon. Pours a nice, rich amber with a thin white head. Toasty malt, with a hint of rye, some yeasty dryness and loads of hops on the palate. Medium to full bodied with a burst of grassy hops on the finish. By far, the most unique Oktfest Ive ever tasted. Definitely brewed outside the style bounds. Another winner from Surly.

Enjoyed at Stubs.For those who dont like hops, dont drink this beer, it is Surly for god sakes, so what do you expect? Easily the best octoberfest beer i have ever had. Ultra hoppy with a nice rye flavor in there for sure. This is certainlly like no other o fest around, and if your a style geek you probably wont like it as its brewed quite a bit outside the ol lines, just the way i like it. Another top notch surly craft!

(on-tap at the Surlyfest Premier at Stub and Herbs) Poured amber with an off-white head.  Aroma was pretty mellow, but mainly consisted of hops, much like the taste.  Taste was all hops initially. As the beer warmed I got the slightest taste of some nice malty sweetness, but that was soon drowned out by the overpowering hoppy finish.

Orange amber color with a decent head of white foam.  Okay head retention.  Moderately malty in the aroma - not bad.  Lots of bitter citrus hops - grapefruit galore.  Too bad as these tend to overshadow the fine maltiness from the aroma.  Interesting take on a lager (I cant call it an o-fest), but for hops Ill stick with Furious.

Sampled draught at the Autumn Brew Review in Minneapolis, October 7 2006.  Hazy, samll-bubbled amber body with a small lasting white foamy head and a bit of lace....smelly, pungent hoppy nose, a bit farmy and leafy with just a trace of smoky/toasty malt lurking....smooth, light apple-cherry notes amidst toasty malt in the moderately sweet, full and slightly sticky body....how they can call this an Oktoberfest I dont know, certainly if rating this to style or as a judge it wouldnt fare well, but judged for just what it is, well its a pretty nice IPA/German lager mix.  Or whatever.
This is like going to an Oktoberfest expecting polka music and getting Pantera.  Suprises you at first, but then it kicks ass!!!!!!!! you like that one Grim!.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2008 Like an Oktoberfest but with the kick you in the nads Surlyness of the Furious in it. Not a session beer. Definately a one or two pinter. But very good, me likey. Copy this one OG. 3.9  Re-rate - I didn’t taste this last year, but I guess they changed the recipe before last year. I’ve had a few cans from this years batch and I don’t like it as much.

Orange colour, more to the red side of things. There was a nice big head on it, and it lasted for quite a while. The aroma was pretty typical of a marzen, but lacked the familiar malty and somewhat spicey profile. The first sip was quite surprising, filled with hops. Mostly bitter, with some grapefruit qualities. I didnt get much else out of the flavour on this, despite the feeling there was more hiding in there.

Bryant Lake Bowl on tap. Out-frikkin-standing. The hops in this were alive and intensly aromatic. The malt body was true to style but thicker than your traditional marzen. Im not a style stickler and have appreciated when brewers like FFF and Surly brew outside of the normal boundaries. I would much rather have this in my stein than anything they would serve in Munich. This is more balanced than the Furious and my favorite so far from these guys.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2006 TennisJoel and I were out for some tennis and beer tonight, and the last stop is Pigfoots place, the Blue Nile.  Al always has some good things on tap.  Little did these two conservatives know that tonight was some sort of party for a Democrat Congressional candidate.  I was afraid the television camera would find me there.  Anyway.  This is a good beer but the least impressive I have tasted form Surly, and I only say that because they have set a high bar for themselves.  This beer has a powerful hop aroma, rather than the light Octobery aroma I expect from a marzen.   The beer is red, and has a large, lacing white head that does last a long time. Flavor is almost all hops, with very light malt, the opposite of what I expect from an Octoberfest.  I like Surly and have yet to have a bad beer from them.  But this beer is predictable however, and it is time for these guys to branch out into something that does not leave a hop burn.  Good work, but go for more guys.

Reviewed from a sample bottle provided by the brewers prior to release. SurlyFest is their take on an Oktoberfest, but, like most of their offerings, isnt likely to satisfy style sticklers. Single-hopped, with Summit, and dry-hopped, using German malt and Crystal Rye. 40 IBUs, between 5 and 6% abv. One single batch brewed, lagered for about 3 months.

Dark orange color, fairly hazed, with a fine slice of bubbly white froth above.

Malty aroma, light fruit, some pumpkin, vegetal, grassy, ...an intriquing blend. Smells like an O-fest, for sure, but doesnt hit me with hops like I anticipated. But definitely hoppier than than the normal Marzen.

Taste: crisp, smooth, slightly sweet, well-balanced, streams through the senses with ease, without being the least bit light bodied or thin. Just delicious. Eternally tasty. Brilliant flavor. Just shines. My vocabulary and sense perception fails me. This is quite a new thing on the tongue and a real, true delight for the tastebuds. Hops really hang in there in the finish, staying on the palate for a spell like a good pale ale or IPA would. A refreshing switch-up for a malty lager!

In other words, I like it! Cant wait to try it fresh off the tap.
Another excellent entry in the growing line of Surliness. Well done, guys!
